topic.title: Formatting and Indenting of XML Documents

body.p: creates XML documents using several different edit modes. In text mode, you as the author decide how the XML file is formatted and indented. In the other modes, and when you switch between modes, must decide how to format and indent the XML. will also format and indent your XML for you in text mode if you use one of the Format and Indent option ( Document Source Format and Indent , Document Source Indent Selection , or Document Source Format and Indent Element ). A number of settings affect how formats and indents XML. Many of these settings have to do with how whitespace is handled.

section.title: Significant and insignificant whitespace in XML
section.p: XML documents are text files that describe complex documents. Some of the white space (spaces, tabs, line feeds, etc.) in the XML document belongs to the document it describes (such as the space between words in a paragraph) and some of it belongs to the XML document (such as a line break between two XML elements). Whitespace belonging to the XML file is called insignificant whitespace. The meaning of the XML would be the same if the insignificant whitespace were removed. Whitespace belonging to the document being described is called significant whitespace.
Knowing when whitespace is significant or insignificant is not always easy. For instance, a paragraph in an XML document might be laid out like this:

body.codeblock: NO Freeman shall be taken or imprisoned, or be disseised of his Freehold, or Liberties, or free Customs, or be outlawed, or exiled, or any other wise destroyed; nor will We not pass upon him, nor condemn him, but by lawful judgment of his Peers, or by the Law of the land. We will sell to no man, we will not deny or defer to any man either Justice or Right.
body.p: By default, XML considers a single whitespace between words to be significant, and all other whitespace to be insignificant. Thus the paragraph above could be written all on one line with no spaces between the start tag and the first word or between the last word and the end tag and the XML parser would see it as exactly the same paragraph. Removing the insignificant space in markup like this is called normalizing space.
But in some cases, all the spaces inside and element should be treated as significant. For example, in a code sample:
body.codeblock:
<codeblock>
class HelloWorld
{
   public static void main(String args[])
   {
      System.out.println("Hello World");
   }
}
</codeblock>
body.p: Here every whitespace character between the codeblock tags should be treated as significant.

section.title: How determines when whitespace is significant
section.p: When formats and indents an XML document, it introduces or removes insignificant whitespace to produce a layout with reasonable line lengths and elements indented to show their place in the hierarchy of the document. To correctly format and indent the XML source, needs to know when to treat whitespace as significant and when to treat it as insignificant. However it is not always possible to tell this from the XML source file alone. uses the following rules to determine when whitespace is significant or insignificant.

If the CSS stylesheet controlling the Author mode editor applies the whitespace: pre setting to an element, all whitespace in that element is treated as significant. No additional spaces are introduced.

dd.p: If a schema is available for the XML document, can use information from the schema to help determine what is significant or insignificant whitespace. To enable schema aware format and indent, and go to Editor Format XML Schema aware format and indent and Editor Edit modes Author Schema aware Schema aware normalization, format and indent .
If an element is listed in the Preserve space list in the XML formatting preferences, all whitespace in that element is treated as significant. No additional spaces are introduced.
If an element is listed in the Default space list in the XML formatting preferences, whitespace in that element is normalized.

If an element is listed in the Mixed content list in the XML formatting preferences, will avoid introducing space anywhere that whitespace does not already exist. Normally, spaces between XML elements are insignificant, but if they occur in the middle of a text string the lack of space between element or between elements and text may be significant (that is, there should not be any space between them in the output). ul.li: If the text node contains other non-white-space characters then the white-spaces are normalized.

If the text node contains only white-spaces:
If the node has a parent element with the CSS display property set to inline then the white-spaces are normalized.
If the left or right sibling is an element with the CSS display property set to inline then the white-spaces are normalized.
If one of its ancestors is an element with the CSS display property set to table then the white-spaces are striped.
Otherwise the white-spaces are ignored.
